required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on July 28, 2020
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

clinical_study.brief_title: Could a Preoperative Feeding Jejunostomy Decrease Sarcopenia for Patients With Oesogastric Adenocarcinoma ?
clinical_study.official_title: Could a Preoperative Feeding Jejunostomy Decrease Sarcopenia for Patients With Oesogastric Adenocarcinoma ?

brief_summary.textblock:
The study of sarcopenia is a subject that is the subject of numerous research and publications, particularly because of its link with a poor prognosis for many cancers.
In an article published by the digestive surgery team, the role of feeding jejunostomy has been demonstrated: it allowed more patients to reach the 2nd stage of surgery and a better tolerance of chemotherapy.
Investigators wanted to study retrospectively the impact of feeding jejunostomy on radiological sarcopenia. Is the positive effect of jejunostomy in gastric cancers associated with a decrease in sarcopenia?

primary_outcome.measure: Evaluate muscle status by CT evaluation of sarcopenia in patients
primary_outcome.time_frame: 24 hour after the realization of the MRI
primary_outcome.description: Evaluate the impact of feeding jejunostomy in patients with gastric cancer

study_pop.textblock: Subject with Stage IB Gastric Cancer and having benefited from the placement or not of a feeding jejunostomy and a control CT performed at the HUS, after the end of the courses of chemotherapy and / or before the surger

criteria.textblock:
Criteria for inclusion:
- Age 18-80 years
- Sex: H or F
- Subject giving their consent for their participation
- Gastric cancers
- stage> IB
- whether or not a feeding jejunostomy
- CT scan performed at the HUS, after the end of the courses of chemotherapy and / or before the surgery.
Exclusion criteria:
- antecedent level L3 surgery,
- psoas hematoma
- No CT performed at HUS at the end of chemotherapy and / or before surgery
- Impossibility of giving the subject informed information
- Subject under the protection of justice
- Subject under guardianship or curatorship
